Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2013 05:35PM Katlebbie wrote: wow I have not been around for a while, so much has happened. I hope everyone is doing better and prayers to the ones who are struggling. I think it was Bella who has some depression going on, same here, I gave myself one more day to be sad, starting tomorrow I will be happy and move on no matter what happens. Too much going to post right now. I do have one question, I hope someone can help. I had reconstruction revision breast surgery on Sept. 20th everything is going well, but I do have one squishy and one not so squishy girl. The PS is not sure that she will soften up. Has anyone else had this problem. I can live with this because they look great it just feels strange. Prayers to all , and a speedy recovery to everyone!
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2013 11:09AM Katlebbie wrote: SunflowersMa - Thank you for your reply! I hope you are right about the insurance, the surgeon sent in the information to the insurance company on the 18th of July and I still haven't heard anything. I called the PS office and they haven't heard anything yet either. The Office Manager had a few choice words about dealing with the insurance company though.... I guess she felt I was someone she could vent to! I was happy to listen!  I'm not sure what type of implants I have now because it's been almost 20 years and all of her records were switched to digital and all hard copies were purged if they were older than 10 years. This is Standard in my state. I used to work in Radiology. I am amazed how easy yours were to remove and that you didn't have them removed in a hospital! Are you still happy with your decision not to replace them? I think I am going to replace, she told me they now have new implants that will not leak even if the shell is ruptured. I, until recently have never had a problem with my implants and I guess I am just used to the way they feel under the pectoral mussel. I was 37 when I had my bmx and after having all of the pain from fibrocystic lumps the tightness was way better than the pain. Anyway thanks again for your reply and I wish you an easy recovery and I hope all goes well for you. Kat
Posts.Title: Implants removal with no Reconstructions- Scared Lezza13 Mommyathome

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2013 08:46PM Katlebbie wrote: I can't believe it's been so long since I posted here. I decided to go with revision reconstruction and the surgery went fine, I'm loving the new "girls" even though one is squishy and one a little more firm and not so squishy. Lezza insurance did pay for the revision surgery. Flat13 I hope all goes well with you and you are happy with your choice. Everyone is different and reconstruction is a personal choice. (((HUGS))) and good wishes to all
Posts.Title: Implants removal with no Reconstructions- Scared Lezza13 Mommyathome

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2013 10:23PM Katlebbie wrote: dogsandjogs Hi I'm still reading through this site trying to find someone who had a rupture in their implant when I noticed that you had yours for 31 years and you have a rupture. I also think one or both of mine are ruptured. Are there any symptoms? I have some pain that I haven't had before plus some back pain in that area. To me they don't look as full as they use too and now they have a different funny shape. I have had mine for 20 years. I saw a PS two weeks ago and she suspects the same plus she says I have capsular contracture . I am waiting for my insurance to see if it is covered which is another question I have if anyone knows the answer to it. Is the surgery to remove and replace with new ones covered? I had my mx because of fibrocystic disease and not cancer. Do you have any answers? Kat

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2013 03:14AM Katlebbie wrote: Hi everyone I keep reading all of your posts but it seems like I am having such a hard time concentrating to answer. (I'm thinking the drugs maybe which I'm trying to cut back on) Mamasix My swelling in my left arm is starting to go down a little more but since I had to go back to work so soon it seems to swell up at the end of the day. I will pray that you find the answer and the swelling goes down. My prayers are going to everyone who is struggling and thank god to everyone who is getting good results. I do have one question, a couple of ladies questioned me on how I was able to keep my old implants.....the Dr. just asked me if I wanted them. Has anyone else got to keep theirs after the surgery. Recap.....mine were 19 years old and I had CC and even though I would have bet that they were leaking they were still in perfect shape so after the surgery she came to make sure I was ok and then just asked me if I wanted them. (they were not TE's) Good night to all may everyone sleep peacefully

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 06:20PM Katlebbie wrote: Oh Ladies I am so sorry to hear that so many of you are still in pain. I also had a rough night even called my daughter because of pain that wouldn't go away even with pain meds on my left side. (I was a little afraid that I was having a heart attack) She is a nurse and gave me all the other symptoms of a heart attack and decided the pain was just because of the reconstruction (funny how my right side had no pain last night). I finally took more meds and ended up sleeping 12 hours and feel so much better today. Bella if you choose to try the e-cig I have some from my mom who is now smoke free for over a year, I would be willing to ship them to you free of charge just so you can try them. They worked for her after smoking for 65 years. She has COPD and was told to quit. Also sending you hugs and prayers. Beatrice, Shadra4611, cjc, school, viv and anyone else who is still struggling sending many soft hugs and well wishes for a speedy recovery. Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2013 03:24AM Katlebbie wrote: KeeB I am so sorry to hear that you have a cold and have to wait until Oct. I pray for a speedy recovery  from your cold and a short wait for a new day for surgery. Mamasixtaz you have such kind words always, you are a blessing, your day is almost here may your wait be a peaceful one. Hobbesla4 good luck on the MRI...I had two, you can always ask your dr. for meds to help relax you before the MRI, during ask for music, and the contrast is not bad, if you are ok with an IV you will do fine.  There is a lot of banging and it is loud and you do have to stay still or the text will take longer. Just try to relax! I will be thinking about you!
